title: Jurgen Klopp is already thinking about summer signings, says former Liverpool favourite Jan Molby
text:

Jurgen Klopp will bring new players to Anfield in the summer, but will continue to promote from within where he finds exceptional young talent. 
That is according to former Liverpool favourite Jan Molby's latest column for the Liverpool Echo , in which he states the belief that the Reds need some new faces if they're to avoid treading water. 
There has been plenty of speculation over the future of Daniel Sturridge , with the Liverpool boss having privately conceded that he needs to find a more reliable striker at the end of the season following further injury setbacks for the England forward this season. Daniel Sturridge has been inconsistent for the Reds under Jurgen Klopp (Photo: Liverpool FC) His Liverpool career has been dogged by injury (Photo: 2017 Liverpool FC) Read More Frank Lampard or Steven Gerrard? Our reporters answer the question that plagued both England legends' careers 
Sturridge was training ahead of Liverpool's Premier League trip to the KC Stadium to face Hull on Saturday, but the out-of-sorts striker knows he is running out of time to change his manager's mind. 
Writing for the Echo , former Reds midfielder Molby said: "I’d have liked us to have made a signing in January. Sometimes you’re just treading water a little bit and you need something to kick-start your season again. We didn’t but now we go into a period of 15 games in 15 weeks which should suit us. 
"In terms of the squad Jurgen Klopp’s shown a lot of patience but I think it’s important to him. Klopp has called on Georginio Wijnaldum to score more goals for Liverpool (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) Klopp has been keen to give youth a chance, blooding the likes of Trent Alexander-Arnold this season (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) Sadio Mane is back with Liverpool after Senegal's AFCON exit (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) 
"When he makes decisions he likes to be able to look the player in the eye and say ‘I gave you every opportunity’. 
"So we look forward to the summer. Klopp will never be a chequebook manager but there will be some new players coming in that's for sure. 
"As much as you want the young players to be involved, only exceptional young players get in the first team and never come out again and the ones we’ve got are still probably 18 months to two years away from being able to challenge for the first team."
